questions.text: A 13-year-old African American girl is brought to the physician for right shoulder pain that has worsened over the past month. She has had many episodes of joint and bone pain and, as a young child, recurrent painful swelling in her hands and feet. Physical examination shows tenderness of the right anterior humerus without swelling or skin changes. Active and passive range of motion of the right shoulder is decreased and there is pain with movement. The leukocyte count is 4600/mm3. An x-ray of the right shoulder shows subchondral lucency of the humeral head with sclerosis and joint space narrowing. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's shoulder pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis results from infection (usually bacterial) within a joint space. It is typically monoarticular and acute and classically manifests with the triad of joint pain, restricted range of motion, and fever. This patient's SCD puts her at increased risk of developing septic arthritis. However, the insidious symptom onset without fever, joint swelling, or warmth, as well as her normal leukocyte count, make septic arthritis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Crystal arthropathy (e.g., gout, pseudogout) can manifest with episodic monoarthritis or polyarthritis and is typically very painful. However, crystal arthropathy is also characterized by joint swelling, erythema, and systemic symptoms, none of which are seen in this patient. Also, the onset of crystal arthropathy is usually acute (hours to days), and this patient's imaging is not consistent with this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Osteoporosis refers to a loss of bone mineral density and is asymptomatic. Patients with SCD are at increased risk of developing osteoporosis and subsequent pathologic fractures, which would also manifest with acute pain and radiolucency on x-ray. However, additional x-ray findings include decreased cortical thickness and a loss of bony trabeculae, which are not seen in this patient. In addition, this patient’s progressive pain over the course of months is not consistent with a diagnosis of osteoporosis.

D) CORRECT:

Infarction of trabecular bone is characteristic of avascular necrosis, which is most likely due to underlying SCD in this patient and has resulted in gradual onset of constant pain and decreased range of motion. This patient’s radiologic findings (subchondral lucency secondary to microfractures, sclerosis, joint space narrowing) are common in advanced avascular osteonecrosis. Her episodes of hand and foot swelling as a child are typical for dactylitis (due to bone infarction from SCD), which is characterized by a moth-eaten appearance of the bones on x-ray.

E) INCORRECT:

Osteomyelitis is characterized by infection (usually bacterial) of the bone. It typically manifests with progressive pain, tenderness, swelling, and limited range of motion. Systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, night sweats) and elevated inflammatory markers are usually also present. While x-rays are not very sensitive, classic findings include periosteal thickening and soft tissue swelling, which are not seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This adolescent African American girl presents with a history of episodic joint and bone pain and dactylitis, all of which suggest sickle cell disease (SCD). The x-ray findings are consistent with a complication of this disease.

questions.text: A 13-year-old African American boy is brought to the physician because of a 4-week history of left groin and buttock pain. The pain is worse with activity but also present at rest. He has had many episodes of abdominal, back, and chest pain that required hospitalization in the past. He is at the 20th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), blood pressure is 115/82 mm Hg, and pulse is 84/min. Examination shows tenderness over the lateral aspect of the left hip with no swelling, warmth, or erythema. There is pain with passive abduction and internal rotation of the left hip. Leukocyte count is 8,600/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is a common hip disorder in adolescent males and can also present with pain and limited range of motion. However, this patient's low weight and absence of family history make SCFE unlikely. His underlying sickle cell disease, on the other hand, makes a different diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with sickle cell disease are at increased risk of septic arthritis due to functional asplenia (which results from recurrent infarction of the spleen). Septic arthritis can also manifest with severe hip pain and limited range of motion, which are seen in this patient. However, additional symptoms such as fever, joint swelling, and erythema would also be expected. His normal leukocyte count makes this diagnosis unlikely as well.

C) INCORRECT:

Although osteosarcoma can cause pain and limited range of motion in adolescents, it typically involves the distal femur or the proximal tibia. Proximal femoral osteosarcoma is extremely rare. Furthermore, patients with sickle cell disease are not at increased risk of osteosarcoma and are more likely to experience a different complication.

D) CORRECT:

Avascular osteonecrosis of the femoral head is a common complication in patients with sickle cell disease and typically manifests between 7–15 years of age. This adolescent boy's subacute hip pain and lack of systemic symptoms are characteristic of avascular osteonecrosis, which is due to trabecular bone infarction from RBC sickling and vaso-occlusion. The femoral head is commonly affected as a result of poor collateral blood supply. Other risk factors for avascular osteonecrosis of the femoral head include glucocorticoid use, alcohol use, autoimmune diseases (e.g., SLE, antiphospholipid syndrome), and Gaucher disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis is a common cause of self-limited hip pain and limping in children and is often preceded by upper respiratory tract infection. However, most patients with transient synovitis are slightly younger (< 10 years), and this patient's underlying sickle cell disease makes a different diagnosis more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with sickle cell disease are at increased risk of impaired skeletal growth. The etiology is multifactorial and is at least partially due to premature closure of the long bone epiphyses. Although there is evidence of impaired growth in this patient based on his low percentile in height and weight, it would be unlikely to cause subacute, unilateral hip pain.
questions.hint: This patient's pain and examination findings suggest pathology involving the hip. His previous hospitalizations for painful episodes are consistent with underlying sickle cell disease (SCD).

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of worsening confusion over the past 2 hours. She has had fever, productive cough, fatigue, and malaise for the past 2 days. She has not seen a physician in approximately 3 years. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 133/min, respirations are 33/min, and blood pressure is 86/48 mm Hg. Mucous membranes are dry. Pulmonary examination shows subcostal retractions and coarse crackles bilaterally. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8.4 g/dL and her leukocyte count is 16,000/mm3. A peripheral blood smear shows sickled red blood cells. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Salmonella species are the most common cause of osteomyelitis in patients with SCD. Osteomyelitis can manifest with malaise, fever, and lethargy and progress to sepsis. However, this patient does not have localized findings (e.g., tenderness, swelling, redness, warmth), which makes osteomyelitis a less likely cause of her sepsis.

B) CORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia and sepsis in patients with SCD. The spleen is important for the opsonization and elimination of encapsulated bacteria. Patients with SCD often develop functional asplenia (i.e., autosplenectomy) by the age of 2–4 years due to repeated episodes of splenic infarction and are therefore at increased risk for infections by encapsulated pathogens (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus influenzae type b, and Salmonella species).

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with SCD are at increased risk of infection by Neisseria meningitidis, which is a capsulated organism that causes meningitis. However, Neisseria meningitidis would not cause pneumonia.

D) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus can cause bacterial pneumonia, particularly in patients who have cystic fibrosis, alcohol use disorder, a history of using IV drugs, or who are immunocompromised. In addition, S. aureus is a common cause of hospital-acquired pneumonia and often develops as a superinfection in patients with influenza pneumonia. Although most isolates are encapsulated (predominantly with serotypes 5 and 8), S. aureus is not the most common cause of pneumonia or sepsis in patients with SCD.

E) INCORRECT:

Nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae, which are unencapsulated strains of H. influenzae, cause milder infections, such as otitis media, conjunctivitis, and bronchitis. They do not typically cause pneumonia or sepsis. Haemophilus influenzae type b, which is an encapsulated organism, is a common cause of pneumonia and sepsis in patients with SCD.
questions.hint: This patient, who has sickle cell disease (SCD), has developed altered mental status, fever, hypotension, and leukocytosis; these features are concerning for a diagnosis of sepsis. The sepsis in this patient is most likely secondary to pneumonia, which caused her productive cough, tachypnea, and coarse crackles. Patients with SCD have an increased risk of infection by encapsulated pathogens.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy who recently emigrated from Ghana is brought to the physician because of a 5-day history of pain and swelling in his hands. He has had similar episodes in the past. The patient appears distressed. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.5°F). Physical examination shows pallor. The dorsum of his hands and fingers are swollen, warm, and tender to palpation. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery aneurysm is an important complication of Kawasaki disease, a medium-vessel vasculitis that can manifest with distal extremity pain, edema, and fever in children < 5 years of age, all of which apply to this patient. However, the incidence of Kawasaki disease is highest in individuals of Asian descent, whereas this patient comes from Africa. Furthermore, other common features of Kawasaki disease are not seen here, such as conjunctival injection, strawberry tongue, rash, and lymphadenopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Needle-shaped crystals in synovial fluid are consistent with gouty arthritis, which manifests with acute episodes of painful joint swelling. Causes of gout in children include Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, von Gierke disease, and leukemia with tumor lysis. Acute gouty arthritis typically affects one joint at a time; the most common manifestation is monoarthritis of the big toe (podagra). If more than one joint is affected, an asymmetrical distribution rather than a diffuse, symmetrical distribution is expected.

C) INCORRECT:

A salmon-colored macular rash in combination with arthritis, fever, and anemia during childhood is concerning for systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis. However, larger joints (e.g., the knees, wrists, and ankles) would usually also be affected in this condition. This patient's geographical background and lack of other systemic findings (e.g., lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, uveitis) support another diagnosis.
Image Description:

Commonly involved joints for each subtype are highlighted in red.

Also illustrated in systemic JIA are pyrexia, and the extra-articular manifestations of lymphadenopathy, serositis (pleuritis, peritonitis, and/or pericarditis), and hepatosplenomegaly

Note: Anterior uveitis in psoriatic JIA is commonly bilateral and chronic, while in enthesitis-related JIA it more commonly manifests as unilateral flare-ups.

D) INCORRECT:

Thickened heart valves may be observed in carditis accompanying an episode of acute rheumatic fever. While this patient does have arthritis and fever, his arthritis is not migratory and does not affect the large joints (e.g., the knee, wrist, or ankle), as would be expected in rheumatic fever. Furthermore, he has no reported history of pharyngitis, which would warrant clinical suspicion of rheumatic fever.

E) CORRECT:

Microhematuria and macrohematuria can occur in SCD due to sickling of RBCs in the renal papilla, with subsequent infarction and eventual papillary necrosis. Predisposing factors for sickling include hypoxia, acidosis, sudden temperature change, dehydration, stress, and pregnancy. The renal papillae are an area of very low oxygen tension (i.e., low PaO2) and, as such, are especially susceptible to hypoxia and sickling.
questions.hint: Recurrent episodes of diffuse, symmetrical pain and swelling of the hands and/or feet are consistent with dactylitis, which is often the first manifestation of vasoocclusive episodes in patients with sickle cell disease (SCD). This patient's pallor (indicating anemia) and African descent further support the diagnosis of SCD.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy who recently emigrated from sub-Saharan Africa is brought to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever, chills, and productive cough. His mother reports that he has had several episodes of painful swelling of his fingers during infancy that resolved with pain medication. His immunization status is unknown. His temperature is 39.8°C (103.6°F). Examination shows pale conjunctivae and yellow sclerae. There are decreased breath sounds and inspiratory crackles over the left lower lung fields. His hemoglobin concentration is 7 g/dL. Blood cultures grow optochin-sensitive, gram-positive diplococci. A deficiency in which of the following most likely contributed to this patient's infection?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Deficient clearance of bacteria due to functional asplenia has likely contributed to this patient's infection. In most children with sickle cell disease, recurrent splenic infarction results in loss of splenic function by 2–4 years of age. Consequently, IgM production is decreased, which leads to ineffective complement activation and thus, impaired opsonization of bacteria. Since opsonization is the body's primary defense against encapsulated bacteria, the risk for infections with such pathogens (most commonly Streptococcus pneumoniae, as seen in this patient) is increased.

Strategies to prevent infections in patients with SCD include pneumococcal vaccination, meningococcal vaccination, and daily prophylactic penicillin from 3 months of age until at least 5 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Impaired immunoglobulin A (IgA) activity increases the risk for sinopulmonary infections with encapsulated bacteria as well as gastrointestinal infections with Giardia lamblia. This patient has bacteremia due to Streptococcus pneumoniae, an encapsulated pathogen. However, SCD and its complications do not directly affect IgA action.

C) INCORRECT:

A defective respiratory burst increases the risk of infections with catalase-positive organisms (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus) and is the cause of chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). Susceptibility to catalase-negative pathogens, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, is not increased. Moreover, SCD and its complications do not affect respiratory burst. Patients with CGD present with recurrent, severe infections of the lung, skin, lymph nodes, and liver.

D) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of complement components increases the risk of infections with encapsulated pathogens and can be inherited or acquired. This patient has bacteremia due to Streptococcus pneumoniae, an encapsulated pathogen. However, SCD and its complications do not affect complement production because complement is produced in the liver, not the spleen. Moreover, children with inherited complement deficiencies typically experience recurrent unexplained pyogenic infections, such as sinopulmonary infections and meningitis, and this patient has no such history.

E) INCORRECT:

Defective T cell differentiation in the thymus increases the risk of infections with viral and fungal pathogens, but susceptibility to Streptococcus pneumoniae is not increased. Moreover, SCD and its complications do not affect the thymus. Thymus aplasia is the cause of the T cell deficiency seen in patients with DiGeorge syndrome. In addition to recurrent infections, this condition is associated with cardiac anomalies, dysmorphic facial features, cleft palate, and hypocalcemia.
questions.hint: This young boy has findings suggestive of sickle cell disease (SCD), including emigration from sub-Saharan Africa, history of dactylitis as an infant, anemia, and scleral jaundice. He now presents with pneumonia and concurrent bacteremia due to Streptococcus pneumoniae, an encapsulated, optochin-sensitive, gram-positive diplococcus.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-day history of severe left hand pain. He has had similar painful episodes in the past that required hospitalization. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae. There is tenderness on palpation of the wrist and the small joints of the left hand. Peripheral blood smear shows crescent-shaped erythrocytes. He is started on a pharmacologic agent that is known to cause macrocytosis. This drug causes an arrest in which of the following cell cycle phases?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

G0 phase of the cell cycle will be arrested in patients taken chemotherapeutic drugs such as alkylating agents and platinum-based agents. Some alkylating agents have been shown to cause macrocytosis as seen in this patient. Nevertheless, these drugs are not used in long-term therapy of patients with sickle cell disease.

B) INCORRECT:

M phase arrest is seen in patients taking chemotherapeutic agents such as taxanes and vinca alkaloids. These agents have not been demonstrated to cause macrocytosis and would not be used in a patient with sickle cell disease.

C) CORRECT:

Hydroxyurea inhibits ribonucleotide reductase, which inhibits DNA replication and causes cell cycle arrest during the S phase. Hydroxyurea has myelosuppressive effects and has been shown to induce macrocytic anemia characterized by the presence of volumetric macrocytes. It is important to note that these macrocytes are different from the megaloblasts seen in megaloblastic anemia. S phase inhibition and macrocytosis are observed in a wide range of drugs with toxic effects on the bone marrow (e.g., methotrexate, adriamycin, purine antagonists, pyrimidine antagonists, and alkylating agents).

D) INCORRECT:

G2 phase arrest will be seen in patients taking proteasome inhibitors (e.g., bortezomib and carfilzomib) for multiple myeloma or mantle cell lymphoma. The side effect profile of these agents does not include macrocytosis. Furthermore, these agents would not be used in a patient with sickle cell disease.

E) INCORRECT:

G1 phase of the cell cycle will be arrested in patients taking chemotherapeutic drugs like monoclonal antibodies and some tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., gefitinib or erlotinib for non-small lung cell cancer). G1 phase arrest can also be seen in pharmacologic inhibitors of cyclin-dependent kinase. These agents have not been demonstrated to cause macrocytosis and would not be used in a patient with sickle cell disease.
questions.hint: A patient with a frequent history of pain crisis requiring hospitalization and crescent-shaped erythrocytes on blood smear is highly suggestive of sickle cell disease (SCD). The first-line therapy for long-term management of SCD is hydroxyurea. This drug is known to cause macrocytosis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of lightheadedness, intermittent headaches, and easy bruising. Five months ago, she was treated for an episode of thrombophlebitis. Physical examination shows multiple bruises on her limbs. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 900,000/mm3 and elevated levels of serum lactate dehydrogenase and uric acid. Treatment with a medication is begun that is also used in the treatment of sickle cell disease. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for the beneficial effect of this drug in sickle cell disease?

choices.text: Augmentation of red blood cell production
Substitution of cofactors for DNA synthesis
Restoration of the body's iron stores

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of thrombocyte aggregation is the effect of antiplatelet agents. Aspirin, a cyclooxygenase-1 inhibitor, is used to prevent thrombotic events in essential thrombocythemia, which this patient has. However, antiplatelet agents play no role in preventing hemolysis or vaso-occlusive crises in individuals with sickle cell anemia.

B) CORRECT:

Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) does not contain β-globin chains, the mutated component in sickle cell anemia hemoglobin (HbS). Hydroxyurea increases fetal hemoglobin by altering the genetic expression of β-globin chains, with γ-globin chains being produced instead (i.e., HbF created in place of HbS or HbA). This leads to a proportional reduction in sickled hemoglobin, thus decreasing RBC polymerization (HbF does not polymerize) and sickling. Therefore, the number of hemolytic and vaso-occlusive episodes decreases.

Hydroxyurea also has a cytoreductive action, blocking DNA synthesis and cell division by inhibiting ribonucleotide reductase. This makes it a potent antimetabolite and a useful drug in the treatment of myeloproliferative diseases, as this patient has.

C) INCORRECT:

Augmentation of red blood cell production is the effect of recombinant human erythropoietin (rhEPO). This reduces the severity of anemia and need for transfusions in individuals with chronic kidney disease, chemotherapy-induced myelosuppression, and anemia of myelodysplastic syndromes. However, this patient presents with essential thrombocythemia, a myeloproliferative disease that would benefit from treatment with a cytoreductive agent (e.g., an antimetabolite), not an erythropoiesis-stimulating agent. In addition, rhEPO is not preferred in the treatment of sickle cell anemia, as it does not prevent hemolysis or vaso-occlusive crises.

D) INCORRECT:

Substitution of cofactors for DNA synthesis (i.e., Vitamin B12 and/or folic acid) is the primary treatment for megaloblastic anemia. Essential thrombocythemia, which this patient has, is caused by excessive proliferation of megakaryocytes, not ineffective DNA synthesis of erythrocyte precursors. Therefore, vitamin B12 and folic acid are not administered as therapy. In individuals with sickle cell anemia, vitamin B12 and folic acid may be supplemented to support the increased erythropoiesis following a hemolytic crisis. However, they play no role in preventing sickling of RBCs or vaso-occlusive crises.

E) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of stem cell differentiation into megakaryocytes is the mechanism of action of IFN-α, a treatment option for essential thrombocythemia, which this patient has. However, as sickle cell anemia is a genetic mutation affecting hemoglobin, not megakaryocytes, IFN-α would not be beneficial in its management.

F) INCORRECT:

Restoration of the body's iron stores is achieved by either oral or parenteral administration of iron. Individuals with sickle cell anemia can develop iron deficiency secondary to hemolysis and urinary loss of iron. However, iron supplementation is not routinely given to adults with sickle cell anemia, as there is evidence that iron-deficient RBCs are less prone to sickling. (Iron supplementation is, however, recommended for iron-deficient children with sickle cell anemia.) This patient was diagnosed with essential thrombocythemia, a myeloproliferative disorder of platelets that is not treated with iron supplementation.

G) INCORRECT:

Drugs that prevent hemoglobin S (HbS) polymerization are still under investigation and could be the future mainstay of treatment for sickle cell disease. However, the current drug that is beneficial in treating sickle cell anemia and this patient's essential thrombocythemia does not prevent HbS polymerization.
questions.hint: Easy bruising, thrombophlebitis, and symptoms of microvascular disturbance (e.g., lightheadedness, intermittent headaches) in a patient with a dramatically elevated platelet count are suggestive of essential thrombocythemia (ET). The drug used as a cytoreductive agent in patients with ET is hydroxyurea.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the outcomes of a malaria outbreak in an endemic region of Africa. 500 men and 500 women with known malaria exposure are selected to participate in the study. Participants with G6PD deficiency are excluded from the study. The clinical records of the study subjects are reviewed and their peripheral blood smears are evaluated for the presence of Plasmodium trophozoites. Results show that 9% of the exposed population does not have clinical or laboratory evidence of malaria infection. Which of the following best explains the absence of infection seen in this subset of participants?

choices.text: Inherited defect in erythrocyte membrane ankyrin protein
Glutamic acid substitution in the β-globin chain

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Translocation of the c-myc gene causes Burkitt lymphoma, an aggressive, high-grade B-cell lymphoma. It usually occurs in adults with HIV infection or in children, in which it is commonly associated with EBV infection. It is not associated with increased resistance to malaria.

B) INCORRECT:

A defect in erythrocyte membrane ankyrin protein occurs in hereditary spherocytosis (HS), which is the most common inherited hemolytic disease among individuals of Northern European descent. It is characterized by spherical erythrocytes with decreased membrane stability, which renders them more vulnerable to osmotic stress, entrapment within the splenic vasculature (splenomegaly), and extravascular hemolysis. The defect is not associated with increased resistance to malaria.

C) INCORRECT:

A defective ALA synthase gene on chromosome X, which results in ineffective heme synthesis, is seen in sideroblastic anemia, a rare disorder characterized by basophilic stippling and ringed sideroblasts on peripheral blood smear and secondary iron overload. Sideroblastic anemia is not associated with increased resistance to malaria.

D) INCORRECT:

An inherited mutation affecting ribosome synthesis is the underlying cause of Diamond-Blackfan anemia, which manifests with congenital anemia due to impaired erythropoiesis and results in an increased ratio of HbF. Diamond-Blackfan anemia is very rare and while it may confer some protection against malaria (due to the increased ratio of HbF present), it would be unlikely to explain the high percentage of non-infected adults seen in this study.

E) CORRECT:

In sickle cell trait, only one allele of the β-globin gene carries the point substitution of glutamic acid to valine, while the other allele is normal, producing hemoglobin AS (HbAS). While individuals with sickle cell trait are usually asymptomatic, they benefit from heterozygous advantage, which confers resistance to malaria and explains its high frequency in some African populations. While the exact mechanism of resistance is not well understood, it is likely due to impaired parasite growth within RBCs and accelerated sickling of infected RBCs.
questions.hint: Approximately 8–10% of the population in regions of Africa where malaria is endemic are resistant to Plasmodium species (the causative agent of malaria) due to sickle cell trait.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of worsening pain and swelling in both of his hands for 1 week. He appears distressed. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.4°F). Examination shows erythema, swelling, warmth, and tenderness on the dorsum of his hands. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.1 g/dL. A peripheral blood smear is shown. The drug indicated to prevent recurrence of this patient's symptoms is also used to treat which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The first-line treatment for primary syphilis is penicillin, not hydroxyurea. Penicillin is also used for prophylaxis of infection with encapsulated organisms in patients with (functional) asplenia. On blood smear, (functional) asplenia manifests as target cells and/or Howell-Jolly bodies, not sickle cells. While this patient with sickle cell disease is at risk of functional asplenia and should therefore be treated with penicillin until at least the age of five, penicillin is not indicated to prevent recurrence of vaso-occlusive crisis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Hypochromic erythrocytes with a dark central area, a pale ring surrounding the center, and a dark outer rim can be seen (dashed red circles on overlay). Due to this “bullseye” appearance on light microscopy, they are called target cells. On electron microscopy, they would appear bell-shaped (overlay illustration; visual axis in light microscopy depicted in red).

The finding of target cells is nonspecific and may indicate various hemoglobinopathies, such as thalassemia, liver disease, or asplenia.

B) INCORRECT:

Treatment of chronic kidney disease (CKD) includes a salt- and protein-restricted diet as well as dialysis and treatment of associated complications such as hypertension (ACE inhibitor or ARB), hyperlipidemia (statins), diabetes mellitus (insulin), bleeding (desmopressin) or anemia (erythropoietin). In CKD, a blood smear may show echinocytes. Treatment of CKD does not include hydroxyurea.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain; medium power magnification)

There is a mixture of normal erythrocytes, with a uniform, smooth, and rounded surface (blue dashed circles), and erythrocytes, with numerous, evenly spaced, thorny projections (blue circles). These cells are referred to as echinocytes or burr cells.

Echinocytes can occur as a result of oxidative or colloid osmotic stress. They may also be an artifact resulting from prolonged storage of blood samples.

C) INCORRECT:

Megaloblastic anemia is a type of macrocytic anemia that commonly occurs in patients with vitamin B12 or folic acid deficiency. Due to inhibition of DNA synthesis blood cell precursors arrest in the G2 cell phase and continue to grow, resulting in megaloblasts. However, blood smear would show macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils, not sickle cells. Moreover, therapy would include supplementation of folate or vitamin B12, not hydroxyurea.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear

Throughout the specimen, there are cells with an irregular, oval form and marked hyperchromasia (intense staining) that are known as macrocytes (examples indicated by arrows). These are surrounded by normal erythrocytes (examples indicated by arrowheads).

Macrocytes may be found in megaloblastic forms of anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Iron intoxication is especially common in pediatric care (ingestion of red iron tablets mistaken for candy). An iron overload can also be caused by β-thalassemia (major), which can present with severe anemia already in infancy. Insufficient erythropoiesis can lead to extramedullary hematopoiesis as well as bone marrow hyperplasia. However, blood smear would show dacrocytes and/or target cells, not sickle cells. Treatment of either iron intoxication or β-thalassemia would involve deferoxamine, but not hydroxyurea.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Erythrocytes with a teardrop shape can be seen throughout the image (red overlay). The majority of the erythrocytes appear round and normal.

Teardrop-shaped erythrocytes, known as dacrocytes, are found in conditions that involve extramedullary hematopoiesis (e.g., myelofibrosis, thalassemia, splenomegaly).

E) CORRECT:

Hydroxyurea is the first-line treatment for frequent, acute episodes of pain or other vaso-occlusive events as well as severe symptomatic anemia due to sickle cell crisis. Hydroxyurea increases fetal hemoglobin by an unknown mechanism, thus reducing HbS proportionally and decreasing RBC polymerization (HbF does not polymerize). It is also used in the treatment of polycythemia vera and other myeloproliferative disorders. In these conditions, hydroxyurea is beneficial because of its myelosuppressive effects, which are a result of its inhibition of ribonucleoside diphosphate reductase.

F) INCORRECT:

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is a rare acquired hemolytic anemia caused by the destruction of erythrocytes by complement. Treatment includes eculizumab, a monoclonal recombinant antibody that inhibits the immune system by binding to and deactivating complement C5, but not hydroxyurea. Eculizumab is also used to treat some forms of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), but this patient has no symptoms of HUS and a blood smear of a patient with HUS would show schistocytes, not sickle cells.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain; high magnification)

Normal erythrocytes (example indicated by arrow; bottom left) and several fragmented erythrocytes (schistocytes; examples indicated by black dashed circles) with a normal convex side (example marked with red line) and a fragmented side that is concave or straight (example marked with blue line) can be seen. Additionally, multiple erythrocytes with dark staining Howell-Jolly bodies (examples indicated by arrowheads) are present.

Schistocytes are a diagnostic finding in microangiopathic hemolytic anemias. These cellular fragments can also result from mechanical damage to erythrocytes (e.g., due to prosthetic heart valves). Howell-Jolly bodies can occur in functional asplenia or after splenectomy, severe anemia, and bone marrow disorders (e.g., myelodysplastic syndrome).
questions.hint: Given the presence of sickle cells on peripheral blood smear, this patient is likely suffering from a vaso-occlusive episode of dactylitis (hand-foot syndrome) due to sickle cell disease (SCD). Hydroxyurea is a medication that is often used in SCD patients to prevent recurrence of these episodes.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of worsening fatigue. His mother reports that he seems to have trouble keeping up with his older brothers when playing outside. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. A hemoglobin electrophoresis is performed. This patient's results are shown in comparison to those of a patient with known sickle cell anemia and a child with normal hemoglobin. Based on this electrophoresis, which of the following types of hemoglobin are dominant in this patient's blood?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Individuals homozygous for HbC have hemoglobin C disease, which typically manifests with mild anemia. The electrophoresis pattern of a patient with HbC disease would show a single thicker band that migrates even less than HbS.

B) INCORRECT:

Individuals with the hemoglobin C trait would have both HbA and HbC in their blood. Hemoglobin electrophoresis of this patient shows HbC but not HbA. Moreover, hemoglobin C trait is usually an asymptomatic carrier state, unlike this patient with fatigue.

C) INCORRECT:

Individuals heterozygous for the sickle cell trait would have both HbA and HbS in their blood. Hemoglobin electrophoresis of this patient shows HbS but not HbA. Moreover, individuals heterozygous for the sickle cell trait are usually asymptomatic, unlike this patient with fatigue.

D) INCORRECT:

Individuals homozygous for HbS have sickle cell anemia, which could explain this patient's fatigue and conjunctival pallor. However, this patient's electrophoresis pattern is distinct from the sample shown for a person with sickle cell anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

The HbA and HbF electrophoresis pattern is seen in healthy newborns and individuals with hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin, an asymptomatic condition. There is no HbF band on this patient's electrophoresis pattern.

F) INCORRECT:

After 6 months of age, HbA normally accounts for >95% of all hemoglobin (the remainder being HbA2 and HbF). This patient's electrophoresis pattern is distinct from that of the normal sample from a child included in the analysis.

G) CORRECT:

HbA (α2β2), which is the predominant form of hemoglobin by the age of 6 months, migrates farther than HbS, which is the predominant hemoglobin of patients with sickle cell disease. This is because HbS contains a neutral valine residue at position 6 within the beta subunit in place of the normal, negatively charged glutamic acid residue. HbS, in turn, migrates farther than HbC because HbC contains a positively charged lysine residue in the same position. The thin band between HbS and HbA in the sickle cell patient's sample is HbF (α2γ2), which is slightly less negatively charged than HbA but more negatively charged than HbS. HbF is normally present in negligible quantities by early childhood but patients with sickle cell disease often have increased levels of HbF. This patient's hemoglobin electrophoresis shows one band at the position of the HbS band and the other at a position closer to the cathode than HbS. Therefore, this patient has HbSC disease. HbSC patients have milder symptoms than those with homozygous sickle cell anemia (HbSS).
Image Description:

A technique used to separate and quantify the different types of hemoglobin in a sample of blood based on their electrical charge. Hemoglobin is negatively charged at an alkaline pH and migrates toward the anode, forming a band. The degree of negative charge of the hemoglobin molecule determines its migration speed and distance. HbA migrates the fastest and, therefore, the greatest distance, followed by HbF, HbS, and HbC. This illustration depicts the presence and relative concentrations of different types of hemoglobins in health (adult and fetal) and in common hemoglobinopathies.
questions.hint: Hemoglobin electrophoresis separates different types of hemoglobin based on their charge. The more negatively charged a hemoglobin molecule is, the further it will migrate toward the positively charged anode.

A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of fatigue. He reports that during this time he has had occasional palpitations and shortness of breath. He has sickle cell disease. Current medications include hydroxyurea and folic acid. He appears fatigued. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 112/74 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctivae. Cardiac examination shows a midsystolic ejection murmur. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
6.4 g/dl


Leukocyte count
6,000/mm3



Platelet count
168,000/mm3



Mean corpuscular volume
84 μm3



Reticulocyte count
0.1%


Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This boy's anemia is most likely due to an infection with parvovirus B19, which is commonly associated with a transient cessation of erythropoiesis in patients with SCD. In otherwise healthy individuals, red blood cells (RBCs) have a consistent lifespan in balance with new RBC production, so that clinically relevant drops in hemoglobin are very rare. However, patients with underlying hemolytic anemias, such as SCD and hereditary spherocytosis, have RBCs with a decreased lifespan. In these patients, the transient cessation of erythropoiesis may result in an acute drop in Hb with associated reticulocytopenia (i.e., transient aplastic crisis). TAC is usually self-limited and reticulocyte production recurs within a few days.

B) INCORRECT:

Medication-induced hemolysis is commonly seen in patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency. Drugs that may lead to hemolysis include antimalarial drugs (e.g., chloroquine, primaquine), sulfa drugs (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole), nitrofurantoin, isoniazid, dapsone, NSAIDs, ciprofloxacin, and chloramphenicol. Patients often present with an acute drop in hemoglobin. However, hemolytic anemia is usually associated with an increased reticulocyte count. Moreover, this patient has a history of SCD and did not receive any of the previously mentioned medications.
Image Description:

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is the rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and oxidizes glucose-6-P to 6-phosphogluconate while reducing NADP to NADPH. NADPH is essential for converting oxidized glutathione back to its reduced form (GSH). The reduced glutathione is capable of neutralizing reactive oxygen species (e.g., hydrogen peroxide) and free radicals, thereby protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

In G6PD deficiency, glutathione cannot be reduced and erythrocytes become susceptible to oxidative stress, resulting in damage to the erythrocyte membrane, and thus intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.

C) INCORRECT:

A defect in erythrocyte membrane proteins (e.g., ankyrin, spectrin) is seen in patients with hereditary spherocytosis. Like SCD, hereditary spherocytosis may also manifest with aplastic crisis, as seen here. However, hereditary spherocytosis is not known to cause aplastic crisis in patients with SCD.

SCD is associated with abnormal hemoglobin rather than dysfunctional erythrocyte membrane proteins.

D) INCORRECT:

Splenic vaso-occlusion is the underlying cause of splenic sequestration crisis, which usually presents with acute-onset anemia, as seen here. However, unlike in this boy, anemia in splenic sequestration crisis is associated with an increased reticulocyte count. Additionally, patients characteristically have acute left upper quadrant pain (due to rapid enlargement of the spleen) and signs of intravascular volume depletion (e.g., severe hypotension) due to blood being trapped in the spleen. Lastly, splenic sequestration crisis primarily affects infants and young children; older children and adults with SCD often have a nonfunctional, atrophic spleen because of years of damage from sickled cells.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic crisis is the underlying cause of hyperhemolysis. Patients with hyperhemolysis present with acute-onset anemia, as seen here. However, they do not have bone marrow suppression and their reticulocyte count is increased in order to compensate for the decreased hemoglobin.
questions.hint: This patient has sickle cell disease (SCD) and presents with severe symptomatic anemia (evident from his palpitations, shortness of breath, tachycardia, and ejection murmur) and a low reticulocyte count, which suggests impaired erythropoiesis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man with sickle cell disease comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of severe pain in his upper back. He reports that the pain started after a housewarming party at which he consumed multiple alcoholic beverages. He does not have a cough, chest pain, or shortness of breath. He drinks alcoholic beverages occasionally but does not use illicit drugs. Medications include hydroxyurea and folic acid. He looks uncomfortable and is unable to sit up in the examination bed. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 121/68 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 10,200 /mm3, and creatinine concentration is 1.2 mg/dL. In addition to intravenous morphine therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Transfusion of packed red blood cells
Blood cultures and empiric antibiotic therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chest x-ray is the next step in management of suspected acute chest syndrome (ACS) in patients with SCD. Although ACS can be precipitated by vasoocclusive crisis, this patient does not have symptoms of this condition (e.g., fever, cough, chest pain, respiratory distress), and his oxygen saturation is within normal limits.

B) INCORRECT:

Transfusion of packed red blood cells (pRBCs) decreases morbidity and prevents recurrence in patients with vasoocclusive events such as acute chest syndrome, stroke, hepatic sequestration, and multiorgan failure. However, there is no evidence that transfusion of pRBCs benefits patients with ongoing uncomplicated vasoocclusive crises.

C) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures followed by empiric antibiotic therapy are the appropriate management for suspected osteomyelitis. Patients with SCD are at high risk for infection with encapsulated bacteria (e.g., S. pneumoniae) due to functional asplenia, and vertebral osteomyelitis manifests with back pain. However, this patient has no systemic signs of infection (e.g., fever, leukocytosis).

D) INCORRECT:

Hydroxyurea is the first-line agent for the prevention of vasoocclusive crises in SCD, but it is not used for treatment. Patients taking hydroxyurea should continue their regular dose if there are no signs of cytopenia on CBC. Uptitration, if needed, typically occurs in the outpatient setting, and CBC and reticulocyte count should be monitored every 4 weeks for myelosuppression.

E) CORRECT:

Administration of intravenous (IV) fluids is the most appropriate next step in the management of vasoocclusive crisis, which was most likely precipitated by alcohol consumption in this patient. Alcohol inhibits antidiuretic hormone secretion and reduces water absorption in the kidneys, which leads to dehydration and increased risk of erythrocyte sickling. Oral rehydration or IV fluids are appropriate for euvolemic patients. In general, IV fluids should be used judiciously because overhydration can trigger or exacerbate acute chest syndrome. Because hypoxia can worsen erythrocyte sickling, patients with SpO2 of < 95% should be given supplemental oxygen. In addition, pain should be managed with opioids in most patients.
questions.hint: This patient with sickle cell disease (SCD) presents with acute back pain most likely caused by vasoocclusive crisis due to erythrocyte sickling.

Splenectomy may be indicated as a long-term management for recurrent splenic sequestration events and symptomatic hypersplenism. However, this patient requires further acute management before considering splenectomy.

Overtransfusion and raising of the hemoglobin > 8 g/dL should be avoided as the blood trapped in the spleen can return to the circulation and lead to hyperviscosity syndrome and vasoocclusive events. questions.text:
An 18-year-old female college student with sickle cell anemia reports having one to two painful crises a year that require hospitalization. She does not recall having ever received a red-cell transfusion. She has intermittent pain in her extremities and midback, which is relieved by nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs or acetaminophen-hydrocodone.
The patient recalls an episode of confusion, slurred speech, and left-arm and left-leg weakness that occurred in her early teens. Her symptoms resolved within minutes, and she attributed the episode to not sleeping well the previous night. A similar episode occurred again last year when she was studying for finals. Again, she attributed it to sleep deprivation.
Her only regular medication is norethindrone. She reports having occasional migraine headaches that usually occur around her menstrual periods. She does not use tobacco or illicit drugs but does drink alcohol occasionally.
Which one of the following treatments is indicated as first-line therapy for stroke prevention in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Approximately 10% of patients with sickle cell disease have an ischemic stroke by age 20, and approximately 25% have one by age 45.

Chronic red-cell transfusions confer a substantial benefit in stroke prevention in patients with sickle cell disease. In this scenario, the goal of red-cell transfusions is to reduce the overall concentration of sickle hemoglobin to less than 30%. Exchange transfusion is often more effective than a simple transfusion in achieving this goal.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first-line treatment for stroke prevention in a patient with sickle cell disease and a history of transient ischemic attacks is prophylactic red-cell exchange transfusions.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydroxyurea has a role in the prevention of vaso-occlusive crises but is not the first-line treatment for stroke prevention. The time of onset of its action to reduce sickle hemoglobin concentration is measured in weeks to months, not hours. In a person at risk, prompt reduction of sickle hemoglobin concentration is an important goal of treatment. The TWiTCH (T ranscranial Doppler W ith T ransfusions C hanging to H ydroxyurea) trial showed that some patients may be maintained on hydroxyurea without transfusions; however, these patients had already completed at least 2 years of chronic transfusion therapy with normalization of transcranial Doppler velocities and other imaging criteria.

C) INCORRECT:

Aspirin is not indicated because the mechanism of transient ischemic attacks in sickle cell disease is from sickled red cells, not platelet aggregation.

D) INCORRECT:

Sumatriptan is used to manage migraine and would not be helpful in reducing the risk of stroke. Although migraine can manifest with neurologic symptoms, the clinical history usually allows it to be readily distinguished from a transient ischemic attack.

E) INCORRECT:

Iron chelation therapy would be indicated in a patient who has received repeated transfusions and has evidence of iron overload.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman with sickle cell disease (Hb SS) presents for follow-up. She is currently asymptomatic but has had four acute pain episodes and required three red-cell transfusions during the past year. She has never had a stroke or an episode of acute chest syndrome. Her only medication is daily folic acid, and she is up to date on all recommended vaccinations.
Which one of the following treatments would be most appropriate to reduce the frequency of this patient’s acute pain episodes?

choices.text: Blood transfusion to maintain a hemoglobin level >12 g/dL

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iron chelation prevents organ damage in patients with iron overload from blood transfusions but has no role in preventing acute pain episodes.

B) INCORRECT:

To deal with acute pain episodes, patients with sickle cell disease should have a treatment plan that ensures the availability of appropriate analgesics. However, meperidine should be avoided because it can lead to accumulation of the metabolite normeperidine, which can cause central nervous system toxicity.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics have no effect on the frequency of acute pain episodes.

D) INCORRECT:

Blood transfusions are indicated for symptomatic anemia or during an acute chest crisis, but transfusions that lead to a hemoglobin concentration >12 g/dL increase the risk for complications of hyperviscosity.

E) CORRECT:

Hydroxyurea increases levels of hemoglobin F. In a study of patients with sickle cell disease, hydroxyurea treatment reduced the median rate of acute pain episodes by almost half, compared with placebo. The medication also reduced the frequency of acute chest syndrome and the number of transfusions, and a 9-year follow-up showed a 40% reduction in mortality in patients receiving hydroxyurea.

Crizanlizumab, a monoclonal antibody to P-selectin, is a newer medication that has also been shown to be associated with lower rates of sickle cell-related pain crises than placebo.

Key learning point: The first-line medication for reducing the frequency of acute pain episodes in patients with sickle cell disease is hydroxyurea.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman with sickle cell disease presents with chest and back pain and progressive dyspnea. The back pain began 3 days ago and is consistent with previous acute pain episodes. She notes no other inciting illness or trauma.
Her temperature is 38.6°C, her heart rate is 110 beats per minute, her blood pressure is 139/88 mm Hg, and her respiratory rate is 30 breaths per minute. Her oxygen saturation increases from 88% while she is receiving 4 liters of supplemental oxygen to 94% while she is wearing a nonrebreather face mask.
She is hospitalized and started on intravenous fluids, opioid analgesics, and intravenous ceftriaxone and azithromycin. However, she continues to have chest discomfort and difficulty breathing and becomes progressively more dyspneic and hypoxic.
Chest radiography reveals right middle and right lower lobe consolidations without any pleural effusions.
In addition to supportive intensive care and ventilatory support, what management is most appropriate in this patient?

choices.text: Perform an exchange transfusion of red cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The addition of vancomycin would not be needed in this patient. She is already receiving ceftriaxone and azithromycin, and infections do not frequently complicate acute chest syndrome in adults.

B) INCORRECT:

Immunoglobulin is not indicated for the management of the acute chest syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Although patients with acute chest syndrome are at increased risk for developing pulmonary emboli and in this way benefit from prophylactic therapy with low-molecular-weight heparin, intravenous heparin is indicated only in the presence of a pulmonary embolism. The radiographic abnormalities in this patient are not consistent with that diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

Acute chest syndrome is a leading cause of death in adult patients with sickle cell disease. It is defined as chest pain associated with a new opacity on chest radiography and associated fever or respiratory distress.

Acute chest syndrome is preceded by an acute painful crisis in about 50% of cases. The pathophysiologic cause is vasoocclusion in the pulmonary microvasculature, which can be caused by bone-marrow fat emboli, pulmonary infarction, rib or sternal infarction, pneumonia, and pulmonary emboli. There are varying degrees of acute chest syndrome and, correspondingly, various management approaches.

This patient meets the criteria for severe acute chest syndrome, given her pending respiratory failure and multilobar infiltrates on chest radiography. She should be intubated and then should undergo a simple or exchange red-cell transfusion to lower the sickle hemoglobin content to 30%.

Exchange transfusion is the preferred method for treating severely affected adults with acute chest syndrome. Exchange transfusion allows for the rapid transfusion of large amounts of blood, effectively decreasing the sickle hemoglobin percentage while averting the hyperviscosity that may occur if hemoglobin levels exceed 11 g/dL.

Key learning point: Patients with sickle cell disease in whom moderate or severe acute chest syndrome develops should receive short-term care consisting of red-cell exchange transfusion.

E) INCORRECT:

The use of glucocorticoids, such as dexamethasone, is not standard practice for the management of acute chest syndrome; if glucocorticoids are used and then discontinued, a rebound vasoocclusive event can occur.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman presents to establish care. She reports several acute episodes of pain during her lifetime, frequently involving her hips. She has never required hospitalization or intravenous opioids, and she has never been pregnant. She has cousins with sickle cell disease who have had similar painful episodes.
Physical examination shows an enlarged spleen that is palpable 3 cm below the left costal margin.
Laboratory testing shows a normal serum creatinine level and a hemoglobin level of 11.1 g/dL (reference range, 12.0–16.0). Her reticulocyte count is 4.5% red cells (0.5–2.5).
A blood smear reveals many target cells and a few elongated sickle cells.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Beta-thalassemia minor would not lead to pain crises, although it is often characterized by microcytic anemia and target cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Sickle cell trait generally leads to no clinical phenotype. Testing is typically done only in the antenatal setting for preconception counseling.

C) INCORRECT:

Hb SS disease is a much more profound clinical phenotype, with significantly increased pain crises, functional asplenia from a young age, and issues with physical growth and maturation.

D) CORRECT:

Patients with hemoglobin (Hb) SC disease carry one gene for Hb S (the sickle gene) and one gene for Hb C. The combination leads to a phenotype that is less severe than hemoglobin SS disease but more severe than sickle cell trait. Although the clinical presentations of sickle cell disease and sickle cell trait can vary, hemoglobin electrophoresis can be performed to distinguish between them. Patients with hemoglobin SC disease often have splenomegaly, thought to be caused by the increased need of the spleen to cull pitted and damaged erythrocytes. Adults with even mild sickle cell disease are unlikely to have splenomegaly because they experience splenic infarcts during crises. The splenomegaly is an important hint to the presence of SC disease. An additional clue is the presence of target cells.

Key learning point: The combination of mild anemia and infrequent pain crises in a patient with splenomegaly suggests a diagnosis of hemoglobin SC disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Alpha-thalassemia minor (inheritance of two normal Hb A genes and two mutated genes) is generally asymptomatic, except for potential mild microcytosis.

Ursodiol, colesevelam, penicillamine, and pancrelipase are not effective for iron overload.

B) INCORRECT:

Colesevelam is a biliary acid sequestrant.

Ursodiol, colesevelam, penicillamine, and pancrelipase are not effective for iron overload.

C) INCORRECT:

Pancrelipase is indicated in patients with pancreatic insufficiency.

Ursodiol, colesevelam, penicillamine, and pancrelipase are not effective for iron overload.

D) INCORRECT:

Because iron is poorly excreted, the excess iron is deposited in macrophages of the reticuloendothelial system. When this iron burden overwhelms the ability of reticuloendothelial cells to sequester the iron, parenchymal iron overload develops, leading to end-organ dysfunction, especially in the liver, myocardium, and endocrine organs (causing problems such as hyperglycemia).

Iron chelation helps in the management of patients with signs of iron overload. Available treatments include deferoxamine, deferasirox, and deferiprone, all of which are effective at reducing total iron stores and preventing progression of iron overload-associated disease.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a patient with transfusion-induced iron overload with evidence of end-organ dysfunction is iron chelation therapy with a treatment such as deferasirox.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is evaluated in the emergency department for severe pain in his hand. He has a history of sickle cell disease, with two previous hospitalizations for acute pain episodes.
His heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and his temperature is 37.9o C. His lips are dry, and he has pale mucous membranes. His right index finger is mildly swollen and tender. His capillary refill is <2 seconds.
He is given acetaminophen, a bolus of normal saline, and two doses of morphine, with some improvement. After one hour, he is transferred to the ward for further care. On arrival to his hospital room, he is crying and rates his pain as 8 out of 10 on the Wong-Baker FACES pain scale.
What is most appropriate pharmacologic option for this patient's pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A digital nerve block uses injected local anesthetic to provide regional anesthesia to a finger or toe. The effect of the anesthesia is temporary, which makes it ideal for the treatment of a number of acute injuries. However, it is not effective when the duration of symptoms may be longer than an hour, and it is not appropriate treatment for a patient with sickle cell disease having an acute pain episode.

B) INCORRECT:

Ketorolac and acetaminophen could be provided as adjunctive therapy for this patient, but these agents are not sufficient alone for the treatment of severe pain, and clinicians should be aware of the nephrotoxicity that can result from the use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs in patients with sickle cell disease.

C) CORRECT:

Acute pain episodes are common in patients with sickle cell disease, and the treatment depends on the severity of the pain, as rated on an age-appropriate scale.

This patient has severe pain that has not been adequately treated and should now be considered an emergency. A continuous infusion of opioids with patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) should be started immediately. PCA allows for immediate pain relief and can be titrated to an appropriate level by the patient. To minimize the risk of respiratory depression, individuals other than the patient should not push the button on the PCA pump.

Key learning point: Moderate-to-severe pain in children with sickle cell disease should be treated with opioids.

D) INCORRECT:

Hydroxyurea is used to prevent acute pain episodes but does not provide immediate pain relief.

E) INCORRECT:

Ibuprofen is used to treat mild pain in children with sickle cell disease, but it is not adequate for severe pain.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl with a history of sickle cell disease and recurrent acute pain episodes presents to the emergency department with severe bone pain and nausea. The pain began 12 hours ago and has been worsening; the patient rates it at 10/10. She has been unable to take oral medications because of the nausea.
Which one of the following pain management strategies is most appropriate?

choices.text: Promethazine suppository, followed by oral morphine every 4 hours as needed for pain
Promethazine suppository, followed by oral morphine scheduled every 4 hours
Intramuscular ketorolac every 6 hours as needed for pain

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Use of a promethazine suppository followed by oral morphine would not be appropriate in this patient. The suppository may help the nausea and might be administered early in care, but treatment of pain should not be delayed by treatment of nausea. Furthermore, oral pain medication is not likely to be adequate for this patient at this time because of her nausea.

B) CORRECT:

Current guidelines on pain management for children from both the World Health Organization and the American Society of Hematology call for a step-up strategy in which mild pain is treated with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs or acetaminophen, moderate pain is treated with weak opioids, and severe pain is treated with strong opioids, preferably morphine. Pain severity should be assessed regularly, and if the pain does not improve with one level of analgesia, the child should be moved up to the next level.

Oral administration of analgesia is preferred whenever possible (to avoid more painful modes of administration), and the dosing depends on pain severity. For mild pain, analgesia can be dosed as needed. For moderate-to-severe pain, it should be scheduled at regular intervals.

This child has severe, continuous pain and should therefore receive a strong opioid scheduled at regular intervals. Because she cannot tolerate oral medications, intravenous administration is necessary. Given the severity of her pain, an opioid should be chosen instead of acetaminophen.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management for severe, continuous pain in a child is a strong, intravenously administered opioid medication dosed at regular intervals around the clock.

C) INCORRECT:

Use of a promethazine suppository followed by oral morphine would not be appropriate in this patient. The suppository may help the nausea and might be administered early in care, but treatment of pain should not be delayed by treatment of nausea. Furthermore, oral pain medication is not likely to be adequate for this patient at this time because of her nausea.

D) INCORRECT:

Because she cannot tolerate oral medications, intravenous administration is necessary. Given the severity of her pain, an opioid should be chosen instead of acetaminophen.

E) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular ketorolac is not appropriate for this patient for several reasons. First, although ketorolac monotherapy may be used for moderate pain, it is unlikely to provide adequate relief for severe pain; in patients with severe pain, ketorolac is more typically used in conjunction with opioids (for 5 to 7 days). Second, intramuscular administration is not usually recommended for a child. Finally, clinicians should be aware of comorbidities such as peptic ulcer disease and nephrotoxicity that can result from the use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs in patients with sickle cell disease.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy with a history of sickle cell disease complicated by an episode of dactylitis and a previous vasoocclusive episode presents for follow-up. He has no history of stroke. His current medications include folic acid daily, ibuprofen as needed, and acetaminophen-hydrocodone as needed. He is no longer taking penicillin prophylaxis. He has no medication allergies.
He received the following routine childhood immunization series through 4 years of age:

Hepatitis B

Haemophilus influenzae type B
Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine
23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine
Diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis
Inactivated poliovirus
Measles-mumps-rubella
Varicella
Hepatitis A

He received his Covid-19 vaccines last year.
In addition to an annual influenza vaccine, which one of the following vaccines is indicated at this time for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The human papillomavirus vaccine is approved for use in boys age 9 and older.

B) INCORRECT:

Vaccination with Bacille Calmette-Guérin is not recommended for children with sickle cell disease in the United States.

C) INCORRECT:

The tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis booster is not routinely administered to children younger than 11 or 12 years of age if they received their diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis booster at 4 to 5 years of age.

D) INCORRECT:

Serogroup B meningococcal vaccine is indicated for children with sickle cell disease who are 10 years of age or older. It can be administered in combination with quadrivalent meningococcal vaccine either as a pentavalent meningococcal vaccine or as a separate meningococcal B vaccine.

E) CORRECT:

Because of functional asplenia, all children with sickle cell disease are at increased risk for infection due to encapsulated organisms including Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Haemophilus influenzae type B. Thus, in addition to all routine childhood immunizations, these patients should also receive pneumococcal prophylaxis with penicillin as well as early meningococcal vaccination.

The implementation of pneumococcal prophylaxis in patients with sickle cell disease (oral penicillin for young children and routine administration of pneumococcal vaccines) has had a dramatic effect on the incidence of invasive pneumococcal disease in this population — from approximately 6 episodes per 100 patient-years to 0.3–0.5 episodes per 100 patient-years. The recommended pneumococcal vaccination schedule for children with sickle cell disease is as follows:

• Four doses of 15-valent or 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV15 or PCV20) before 23 months of age, on the same schedule as is given to all children
• Two doses of 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23), with the first dose at ≥24 months of age (but at least 8 weeks after the last dose of PCV) and the second dose 5 years later

Children with sickle cell disease who have received the recommended pneumococcal vaccines and are receiving regular medical care can usually discontinue prophylactic penicillin safely at 5 years of age.

In addition to pneumococcal prophylaxis, early meningococcal vaccination is recommended for all children with sickle cell disease. Two doses of quadrivalent meningococcal conjugate vaccine (MenACWY) should be given at least 2 months apart, starting between the ages of 2 years and 10 years. The first dose should not be administered until at least 4 weeks after completion of the PCV doses.

Key learning point: All children with functional or anatomic asplenia should receive a two-dose series of meningococcal conjugate vaccine starting between the ages of 2 years and 10 years.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl with sickle cell disease is admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with fever and severe respiratory distress. She has had a mild cough for 3 days but today developed chest pain, difficulty breathing, and a fever of 40°C. She typically has a hemoglobin level of 8 g/dL (reference range, 11.5–15.5) and an oxygen saturation >90% while breathing ambient air. She has never been admitted to the hospital before but has had three vaso-occlusive pain episodes managed at home. At home, she takes folic acid and albuterol as needed.
At admission, her temperature is 39.5°C, her heart rate is 137 beats per minute, her respiratory rate is 58 breaths per minute, and her oxyhemoglobin saturation is 84% while she is breathing ambient air. Her conjunctivae are pale, and she shows signs of dehydration with tacky mucous membranes. She has significantly increased work of breathing with suprasternal, subcostal, and intercostal retractions. Auscultation reveals a 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, diminished bibasilar breath sounds, and scattered wheezes and crackles in the left lower base.
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following interventions should be added to this patient’s long-term regimen to reduce her risk of developing this complication again?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a complex, chronic, systemic condition that affects virtually every organ system. Although the genetics of SCD are relatively simple, the disease severity varies substantially, and the pathophysiology behind this variance is not well understood. Complications that increase morbidity and mortality in patients with SCD include (but are not limited to) recurrent vaso-occlusive pain episodes, bacterial infection, acute renal failure, hepatobiliary complications, acute anemia, acute stroke, and acute chest syndrome. This particular patient presents with acute chest syndrome (ACS), an acute lung injury associated with chest pain, fever, tachypnea, wheeze, cough, hypoxemia, and the presence of a new pulmonary infiltrate on chest radiograph that is consistent with alveolar consolidation involving at least one complete lung segment. ACS is the second most common reason for hospitalization in patients with SCD (after vaso-occlusive pain events) and is a leading cause of SCD-related morbidity and mortality.

Various interventions are used to reduce morbidity and mortality in patients with severe SCD, and even more are under investigation and development. Hydroxyurea reduces SCD severity through multiple mechanisms, including the induction of fetal hemoglobin production, the release of nitric oxide (improving pulmonary blood flow and reducing the risk of pulmonary hypertension), and the reduction of neutrophil and platelet counts (leading to decreased inflammation and thrombosis). It has been shown to be efficacious and safe in patients with a history of ACS or symptomatic anemia — and is specifically indicated for patients with SCD who have had three or more pain episodes within a 12-month period. Guidelines from the National Heart, Blood, and Lung Institute recommend offering hydroxyurea treatment to all children over the age of 9 months.

Key learning point: To reduce the risk of complications such as acute chest syndrome, children and adolescents with sickle cell disease should be offered treatment with hydroxyurea.

B) INCORRECT:

Rivipansel, a pan-selectin inhibitor, has been shown to reduce the duration of acute pain episodes and the need for intravenous opioid use in patients with sickle cell disease, but it is still in development and is not indicated for the treatment of ACS.

C) INCORRECT:

Long-term transfusion therapy is used to raise the hemoglobin A concentration and reduce the concentration of hemoglobin S. However, this intervention is not without substantial risk, as each transfusion represents exposure to a new blood product and thus an opportunity to develop antibodies and transfusion reactions. Long-term transfusion therapy is usually considered after transcranial Doppler ultrasound has suggested abnormal velocities and therefore an increased risk of stroke. This patient has not undergone transcranial Doppler ultrasound.

D) INCORRECT:

Functional asplenia occurs at an early age in patients with SCD and increases their risk for infection. Key strategies for reducing this risk include providing penicillin prophylaxis in children under age 5, maintaining up-to-date immunizations (especially against pneumococcus and meningococcus), and educating patients and their families to seek medical care for every fever. Penicillin prophylaxis is not recommended for children over 5 years of age.

E) INCORRECT:

A high percentage of patients with SCD suffer from asthma, and this can increase their risk for ACS. However, glucocorticoids (particularly systemic glucocorticoids) are typically avoided in patients with SCD because they increase the rate of vaso-occlusive pain events.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy with sickle cell disease is hospitalized for fever, cough, and worsening anemia. He has had a cough and runny nose for one week and developed fever and body aches. Most of his classmates have been sick with similar symptoms. He has been hospitalized three times before, twice for acute pain episodes and once for fever. He takes folic acid, penicillin, and hydroxyurea daily. His baseline hemoglobin level is 9.5 g/dL (reference range, 11.5–13.5).
On admission, he has a temperature of 38.1°C, a heart rate of 153 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 92% while breathing ambient air. He is pale but generally appears well. Cardiac examination is notable for a 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. Both lungs are clear to auscultation. His liver is palpable just below the right costal margin, and his spleen tip is felt 2 cm below the left costal margin, which is his baseline.
