Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Splenic sequestration is a common cause of acute anemia in children with SCD. In contrast to aplastic crisis, splenic sequestration manifests with reticulocytosis to compensate for erythrocytes that are acutely sequestered in splenic tissue. Affected patients typically have an increase in splenomegaly from baseline. The absence of splenomegaly beyond baseline in this patient coupled with his low reticulocyte count makes splenic sequestration very unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Acute worsening of chronic anemia in sickle cell disease (SCD) warrants thorough investigation, as it often signals severe underlying illness. The first step in the workup includes an assessment of reticulocyte count to determine whether the anemia stems from diminished erythrocyte production or increased loss of erythrocytes (e.g., from hemolysis or bleeding). This patient’s reticulocyte count is inappropriately low, indicating aplastic crisis, which is most commonly caused by bone-marrow suppression due to infection with parvovirus B19.

Key learning point: Acute anemia and a suppressed reticulocyte count in a patient with sickle cell disease and viral symptoms suggests a diagnosis of aplastic crisis.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with SCD typically take folic acid supplements because of increased folate consumption from erythrocyte destruction. However, folic acid deficiency would manifest with an increased mean corpuscular volume and megaloblastic anemia, neither of which are seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

In contrast to aplastic crisis, hepatic sequestration manifests with reticulocytosis to compensate for erythrocytes that are acutely sequestered in hepatic tissue. Affected patients typically have an increase in hepatomegaly from baseline. The absence of hepatomegaly beyond baseline in this patient coupled with his low reticulocyte count makes hepatic sequestration very unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute chest syndrome (ACS) may manifest with worsening anemia, but diagnosis requires the presence of a new pulmonary infiltrate on chest radiograph, which this patient does not have. In addition, patients with acute chest syndrome (ACS) typically have a normal or elevated reticulocyte count.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy with sickle cell disease presents to the emergency department with chest and back pain and progressive dyspnea. The back pain began 3 days ago and is consistent with previous acute pain episodes. The patient and his family do not report any other inciting illness or trauma. He had a cholecystectomy at 7 years of age but has had no episodes of acute chest syndrome.
His temperature is 38.6°C, his heart rate is 110 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 129/88 mm Hg, and his respiratory rate is 30 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation increases from 88% to 96% when he is receiving one liter of supplemental oxygen via nasal canula. His hemoglobin level, which is 8.5 g/dL at baseline, is currently 7 g/dL (reference range, 11.5–15.5).
He is hospitalized and started on intravenous fluids, opioid analgesics, and broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy with intravenous ceftriaxone and azithromycin. However, overnight, he continues to have chest discomfort and difficulty breathing and becomes progressively more dyspneic and hypoxemic, requiring 4 liters of supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula to maintain an oxygen saturation >96%. Chest radiography reveals right middle and right lower lobe consolidations without any pleural effusions.
In addition to supportive intensive care and ventilatory support, what management is most appropriate in this patient?

choices.text: Administer phenotypically matched packed red cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although patients with ACS are at increased risk for developing pulmonary emboli and in this way benefit from prophylactic therapy with low-molecular-weight heparin, intravenous heparin is indicated only in the presence of a pulmonary embolism. The radiographic abnormalities in this patient are not consistent with that diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

The use of glucocorticoids, such as dexamethasone, is not standard practice for the management of ACS; if glucocorticoids are used and then discontinued, a rebound vasoocclusive event can occur with life-threatening consequences. Any glucocorticoids that are started in an acute situation should be tapered to prevent rebound.

C) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin is not needed in this patient. He is already receiving ceftriaxone and azithromycin, which cover the typical infectious contributors to ACS.

D) INCORRECT:

Immunoglobulin is not indicated for the management of ACS.

E) CORRECT:

Acute chest syndrome (ACS) is the leading cause of death in patients of all ages with sickle cell disease. Although various definitions of ACS are used in clinical practice, they typically include a new pulmonary infiltrate identified by imaging and accompanied by either chest pain or fever; ACS can also include tachypnea, wheezing, cough, or leukocytosis.

ACS is caused by vasoocclusion in the pulmonary microvasculature. The most common etiology is infection, but bone-marrow fat emboli, pulmonary infarction, rib or sternal infarction, and pulmonary emboli can also contribute. Mycoplasma, chlamydia, and viral pneumonia are common. The risk of ACS among patients with sickle cell disease is increased in the postoperative setting and in those with asthma.

This patient meets criteria for ACS, given his hypoxemia and multilobar infiltrates on chest radiography, and should receive a transfusion of packed red cells without delay. It is important that the blood be both sickle negative and phenotypically matched because patients with sickle cell disease are at high risk for alloimmunization due to repeated transfusion needs.

Red-cell exchange is the optimal transfusion approach for a patient with progressively symptomatic ACS, but it can take time to arrange, especially for a patient being managed in the middle of the night, as in this case. Depending on hospital infrastructure, it may be clinically expedient to proceed with a simple transfusion while arranging for possible exchange, rather than delaying an intervention overnight. Providing phenotypically matched red cells as a simple transfusion will lower the sickle hemoglobin content (less sickling) and increase the patient’s oxygen-carrying capacity. Because this patient has a hemoglobin concentration of 7 g/dL, he can tolerate a simple transfusion without creating hyperviscosity. The goal of a simple transfusion in this setting is a hemoglobin level >10 g/dL (close to 11 g/dL), although caution with volume is also important to consider.

If the patient were to experience rapid progression of ACS despite a simple transfusion (as demonstrated by hypoxemia despite supplemental oxygen, increasing respiratory distress, progressive pulmonary infiltrates, or a decline in hemoglobin concentration), then red-cell exchange transfusion would be urgently indicated. Red-cell exchange is the most reliable method of lowering a patient’s sickle hemoglobin content to 30%. If this patient had hemoglobin SC disease, hemoglobin S/beta-thalassemia, or a starting hemoglobin concentration ≥10 g/dL for some other reason, then an exchange (rather than simple) transfusion would be necessary in order to avoid hyperviscosity (hemoglobin >11 g/dL).

Key learning point: Patients with sickle cell disease who develop acute chest syndrome with hypoxemia should receive packed red cells, either by simple or exchange transfusion, depending on the situation.

questions.text: A 14-year-old Somali boy is brought to the emergency department by his legal guardian because of a painful penile erection since he woke up 3 hours ago. He recently emigrated to the United States from a refugee camp, and his past medical history is unknown. On further questioning, his guardian reports that the child is often fatigued. Examination shows an ejection systolic murmur heard over the precordium. Examination of the genitalia shows an engorged, tumescent penis. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Priapism may occur in some types of acute leukemia as a result of hyperleukocytosis, which causes impaired blood flow, but is very rare. A different diagnosis is more likely in this patient, especially considering that his ethnic background puts him at special risk for the most frequent cause of priapism in children and young teens.

B) CORRECT:

Sickle cell disease (SCD) refers to a group of hereditary hemoglobinopathies causing chronic hemolytic anemia. SCD primarily affects individuals of African or Eastern Mediterranean descent. Clinical features include fatigue, vasoocclusive pain (affecting the joints and bones), and a high risk of infection. Physical examination commonly reveals heart murmurs as a result of increased cardiac output (which is a response to hypoxia). Priapism, another vasoocclusive phenomenon, is a common problem in patients with this illness. SCD is the most frequent cause of priapism in children and young teens.

C) INCORRECT:

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma, the most frequent type of lymphoma among children, may cause fatigue and possibly priapism as a result of hyperleukocytosis, which causes impaired blood flow. However, the occurrence of priapism in patients with lymphoma is very rare. A different diagnosis is more likely in this patient, especially considering that his ethnic background puts him at special risk for the most frequent cause of priapism in children and young teens.

D) INCORRECT:

Worldwide idiopathic priapism is the most common type of priapism among adult patients (but not in the United States). However, it is usually possible to identify a cause of this condition in young teens.

E) INCORRECT:

Sildenafil is the most common cause of priapism among adults in the United States but is rare in teenagers. This patient's presentation (past fatigue) instead suggests a specific hematological disorder that also causes priapism.
questions.hint: Venous vascular occlusion leading to blood stasis in the corpora cavernosa is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's priapism (prolonged engorged, tumescent penis).

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy with sickle cell disease is brought to the office because of a 10-day history of intermittent fevers and painful swelling of the right ankle. Current medications include hydroxyurea and acetaminophen as needed for ankle pain. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 14/min and blood pressure is 125/68 mm Hg. Examination shows a tender, swollen, and erythematous right ankle with point tenderness over the medial malleolus. X-ray of the right ankle demonstrates marked periosteal thickening and elevation, as well as a central sclerotic lesion with a lucent rim over the right medial malleolus. A bone biopsy culture confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae, an encapsulated bacteria, is the most common cause of bacteremia, sepsis, and meningitis in patients with SCD. However, it is a less common cause of osteomyelitis.

B) INCORRECT:

E. coli and other gram-negative bacteria can cause osteomyelitis in neonates, children, and adults. This bacteria is frequently identified in patients with SCD that have osteomyelitis. However, another organism is more commonly found.

C) INCORRECT:

Group A Streptococcus is a common cause of osteomyelitis in infants and children (up to 8% of cases). However, this patient's history of SCD makes another organism more likely.

D) CORRECT:

Salmonella enterica, an encapsulated bacteria, is the most likely cause of this patient's osteomyelitis. In the US and Europe, S. enterica is the most common pathogen in SCD-associated osteomyelitis due to the functional asplenia common to this population, induced by chronic splenic occlusions and infarctions.

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of osteomyelitis in patients with SCD in Africa and the Middle East and accounts for the majority of acute osteomyelitis cases worldwide.

E) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa osteomyelitis is seen most often in adult IV drug users. It is typically only identified in pediatric populations following puncture wounds to the foot, such as stepping on a nail. This patient has no history of acute trauma to his foot, making P. aeruginosa an unlikely cause.
questions.hint: A history of fevers and bone point tenderness with an x-ray showing periosteal elevations and sclerotic changes is particularly concerning for osteomyelitis. Sickle cell disease (SCD) predisposes to infection with encapsulated bacteria because of the functional asplenia present in most patients by the age of 4.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of bilateral hand pain and swelling. Two weeks ago, the patient had a low-grade fever and lace-like rash on her arms and trunk for several days. The patient appears to be in distress. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.4°F), pulse is 130/min, and respirations are 25/min. The dorsum of her hands and fingers are erythematous, swollen, warm, and tender to palpation. Her hemoglobin concentration is 9.1 g/dL and leukocyte count is 8000/mm3. A peripheral blood smear shows numerous sickle to crescent-shaped red blood cells. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention to reduce the recurrence of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with SCD, blood transfusions are indicated primarily for symptomatic treatment of acute complications (e.g., hemolytic, aplastic, or sequestration crises), preventing chronic complications (stroke), or before surgery. Recommendations vary among institutions but are largely determined by decreases from the baseline Hb levels (typically between ∼ 7–11 g/dL) and the patient's condition. For example, RBC transfusion may be considered after a fall of 2 g/dL and/or if the patient has severe symptoms. This patient's history of recent fever and a lace-like rash suggests parvovirus B19 infection, which is associated with an increased risk for aplastic crisis in patients with SCD. However, her normal leukocyte count and only moderate anemia make aplastic crisis unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Hydroxyurea is indicated in all infants > 9 months, children, and adolescents with sickle cell anemia regardless of symptom severity because it reduces the incidence of acute vasoocclusive episodes and improves survival. The mechanism of action of hydroxyurea is not entirely understood, but the agent likely stimulates erythropoiesis and increases fetal hemoglobin so that the amount of sickled hemoglobin is proportionally reduced.

Indications for hydroxyurea therapy for adults with SCD include frequent (≥ 3 episodes/year) acute pain episodes or other vasoocclusive events, severe symptomatic anemia, and a history of severe and/or recurrent acute chest syndrome.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Numerous crescent-shaped erythrocytes, known as “sickle cells,” can be seen (examples indicated by blue overlay; two normal erythrocytes are indicated by arrowheads for comparison). Erythrocytes with a red center and a white contouring ring, known as “target cells” (yellow overlay; cf. illustration) are visible at the bottom of the image.

Sickle cells are pathognomonic of sickle-cell disease. Target cells can be found in sickle-cell disease and other hemoglobinopathies.

C) INCORRECT:

Red cell exchange (RCE) transfusions are used in patients with SCD. However, RCE is typically used to treat acute life-threatening SCD complications such as ischemic stroke and is not considered a first-line or long-term treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are used in the treatment of rheumatological diseases (e.g., juvenile rheumatoid arthritis). These diseases can lead to low-grade fevers, rashes, and pain in the extremities. However, this patient's blood smear, acute onset of symptoms, lack of morning stiffness, and generalized swelling of both hands make a complication of SCD more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Although penicillin prophylaxis would be indicated in this patient (and all other patients with SCD until the age of five), it would do nothing to prevent this patient's current ailment in the future, which is caused by vasoocclusions of the small bones of the hand rather than a bacterial infection.
questions.hint: This patient's peripheral blood smear shows numerous sickle to crescent-shaped red blood cells (i.e., sickle cells), indicating sickle cell disease (SCD). Dactylitis is often the first manifestation of vasoocclusive episodes, which can also cause fever.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with sickle cell disease is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of generalized fatigue, myalgia, and fever. His current medications include hydroxyurea and folic acid. He appears ill. His temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), pulse is 103/min, and respirations are 28/min. Examination shows pale conjunctivae. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.3 g/dL and leukocyte count is 14,100/mm3. Intravenous fluid is administered and blood cultures are obtained. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Red cell exchange transfusion is a cornerstone of treating acute complications of SCD, such as stroke, acute chest syndrome, or multi-organ failure. However, this patient's presentation is most concerning for infection. The current guidelines for exchange transfusion in patients with SCD do not call for its use in cases of suspected sepsis or bacteremia, making this an inappropriate treatment.

B) CORRECT:

Intravenous third-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone) is the antibiotic therapy of choice in patients with SCD who present with fever. Individuals with SCD generally develop functional asplenia by 4 years of age, and it makes them more susceptible to infections, especially with encapsulated bacteria. Because of the increased risk of developing sepsis, patients with SCD should always receive broad-spectrum empiric antibiotics if they present with fever or other signs of infection, regardless of the presence of a localizing infection (such as otitis media). The common gram-positive (Streptococcus pneumoniae and Staphylococcus aureus) and gram-negative (Salmonella and E. coli) infections seen in SCD are covered by ceftriaxone. In cases of resistant S. pneumoniae, increased dosing may be required.

C) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is a second-line treatment for patients with SCD and suspected sepsis who also have a documented allergy to first-line treatment. This patient has no history of allergic reactions to antibiotics. Even more importantly, fluoroquinolones are contraindicated in children because they can damage developing cartilage and bones.

D) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin may be added to the first-line therapy for suspected sepsis in patients with SCD if there is also a concern for meningitis. Meningitis should be considered in patients with SCD if altered mental status, seizures, or focal neurological abnormalities (such as cranial nerve palsy) are present. This patient has an unremarkable neurological exam. Though a lumbar puncture may be indicated, empiric treatment for meningitis with vancomycin would be inappropriate at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin is reserved for use in patients with SCD and suspected sepsis who also have a documented allergy to the first-line treatment. This patient has no history of medication allergies so clindamycin is not an appropriate medication.
questions.hint: Treatment should be effective against the most common organisms (i.e., S. pneumoniae, Salmonella, E. coli, S. aureus) in sickle cell disease (SCD).

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a 4-hour history of pain in his hands. He has never had an episode similar to this. He was born at term and has been otherwise healthy. His family immigrated to the US from Equatorial Guinea 2 years ago. He appears to be in acute distress. His temperature is 38.2ºC (100.8ºF), pulse is 120/min, and respirations are 28/min. There is tenderness, warmth, erythema, and edema of the fingers of both hands. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in diagnosis?

choices.text: MRI of the hands and feet

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A bone biopsy is a confirmatory test for osteomyelitis and osteonecrosis, both of which manifest with acute pain and erythema, and should be performed, if possible, prior to initiating antibiotic therapy. However, the onset of osteomyelitis is typically more insidious, progressing over several days. Bone biopsy is not the most appropriate initial step in the diagnosis of SCD.

B) INCORRECT:

Genetic testing for SCD (i.e., testing for defective sickle cell genes) is usually only conducted as part of prenatal testing. Fetal DNA samples can be obtained by chorionic villus sampling at 10–13 weeks of gestation. Genetic testing is not typically used to diagnose SCD in newborns, children, or adults.

C) CORRECT:

A peripheral blood smear is the preferred initial diagnostic test in cases of suspected sickle cell disease. By directly visualizing the blood under a microscope, the presence of the following features can be assessed: sickle cells (drepanocytes), target cells, reticulocytes, and Howell-Jolly bodies. In a patient having a vasoocclusive crisis, the detection of these features is the first step in confirming SCD.

Liquid chromatography and isoelectric focusing to quantify hemoglobin subtypes are the best confirmatory tests for SCD because they can accurately differentiate between the homozygote (sickle cell disease) and heterozygote subtypes (sickle cell trait).

D) INCORRECT:

MRI of the hands and feet can be used to evaluate for osteomyelitis and osteonecrosis (e.g., due to acute bone infarction), both of which manifest with acute pain and erythema. In patients with recurrent vasoocclusive crises, cyclic bone infarcts can lead to osteonecrosis. However, this very young patient is having his first vasoocclusive crisis and is unlikely to have developed osteonecrosis. MRI is not the most appropriate initial step in diagnosis of this patient's underlying condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemoglobin electrophoresis can be used to screen for and diagnose hemoglobinopathies (e.g., sickle cell disease, thalassemias, hemoglobin C disease). This test is used for confirmatory testing of SCD and can be used to distinguish between the homozygote (SCD) and heterozygote subtypes (sickle cell trait). However, hemoglobin electrophoresis is not the most appropriate initial step in diagnosis for this patient, who is currently having a vasoocclusive crisis.
questions.hint: The presence of dactylitis in a child of African descent should raise concern for a vasoocclusive crisis and sickle cell disease (SCD).

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy with sickle cell disease is hospitalized for fever, cough, and worsening anemia. He has had a cough and runny nose for one week and developed fever and body aches. Most of his classmates have been sick with similar symptoms. He takes folic acid, penicillin, and hydroxyurea daily. His baseline hemoglobin level is 9.5 g/dL. On admission, he has a temperature of 38.1°C (100.5°F), pulse 153/min, respirations 30/min, and an oxygen saturation of 92% while breathing ambient air. He is pale but generally appears well. Cardiac examination is notable for a 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. Both lungs are clear to auscultation. His liver is palpable just below the right costal margin, and his spleen tip is felt 2 cm below the left costal margin, which is his baseline. A chest radiograph is normal. Laboratory testing yields the following results:


Leukocyte count
3500/mm3



Hemoglobin
6.2 g/dL


Hematocrit
19.0


Platelet count
103,000/mm3



Reticulocyte count
0.5%


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Splenic sequestration is a common cause of acute anemia in children with SCD. In contrast to aplastic crisis, splenic sequestration manifests with reticulocytosis to compensate for erythrocytes that are acutely sequestered in splenic tissue. Affected patients typically have an increase in splenomegaly from baseline. The absence of splenomegaly beyond baseline in this patient coupled with his low reticulocyte count makes splenic sequestration very unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Acute worsening of chronic anemia in sickle cell disease (SCD) warrants thorough investigation, as it often signals severe underlying illness. The first step in the workup includes an assessment of reticulocyte count to determine whether the anemia stems from diminished erythrocyte production or increased loss of erythrocytes (e.g., from hemolysis or bleeding). This patient’s reticulocyte count is inappropriately low, indicating aplastic crisis, which is most commonly caused by bone-marrow suppression due to infection with parvovirus B19.

Key learning point: Acute anemia and a suppressed reticulocyte count in a patient with sickle cell disease and viral symptoms suggests a diagnosis of aplastic crisis.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with SCD typically take folic acid supplements because of increased folate consumption from erythrocyte destruction. However, folic acid deficiency would manifest with an increased mean corpuscular volume and megaloblastic anemia, neither of which are seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

In contrast to aplastic crisis, hepatic sequestration manifests with reticulocytosis to compensate for erythrocytes that are acutely sequestered in hepatic tissue. Affected patients typically have an increase in hepatomegaly from baseline. The absence of hepatomegaly beyond baseline in this patient coupled with his low reticulocyte count makes hepatic sequestration very unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute chest syndrome (ACS) may manifest with worsening anemia, but diagnosis requires the presence of a new pulmonary infiltrate on chest radiograph, which this patient does not have. In addition, patients with acute chest syndrome (ACS) typically have a normal or elevated reticulocyte count.
questions.hint: This condition typically resolves within 2 to 14 days.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy with sickle cell disease is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of word-finding difficulty, speech slurring, and weakness and sensory loss of his right arm and leg. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. He follows commands but has nonfluent aphasia. Examination shows marked weakness and decreased sensation of the right upper and lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Babinski sign is present on the right. An MRI scan of the brain shows signs of an evolving cerebral infarction on the patient's left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Immediate exchange transfusion is the first-line therapy in SCD patients with an acute ischemic stroke. During exchange transfusion, erythrocytes with HbS are removed and exchanged with HbS-free erythrocytes, reducing both the concentration of HbS and the rate of vasoocclusion, as well as increasing oxygen delivery. Although exchange transfusion improves outcomes, it does not reverse pre-existing vasoocclusion. In this patient, supplemental oxygen should also be administered to maintain a saturation above 95%.

Prevention of stroke in children with SCD includes screening with transcranial Doppler ultrasound. Identified high-risk patients, as well as children who have already had an ischemic stroke, should receive chronic blood transfusions to lower the proportion of HbS.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous thrombolytic therapy with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) is indicated for acute ischemic stroke and is typically administered within 4.5 hours of symptom onset (but can be used later under specialist guidance). Most ischemic strokes are caused by thrombi, but this patient's symptoms are most likely due to the clumping of sickled red blood cells, for which tPA therapy is not effective. In addition, this patient is only 5 years of age, and tPA is not FDA-approved for the treatment of stroke in individuals < 18 years. A different therapy that has a rapid effect and allows for the control of HbS levels is more appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydroxyurea therapy is considered a first-line treatment for primary prevention of vasoocclusive crises and is used in the management of anemia in SCD. As it functions primarily by raising fetal hemoglobin levels, which can take several months to increase significantly, hydroxyurea would not be helpful in the management of an acute ischemic stroke. However, this patient should be started on hydroxyurea before leaving the hospital, as it has been proven to improve survival outcomes and reduce complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Although patients with SCD are considered hypercoagulable at baseline, anticoagulation is not recommended for patients with SCD with an acute ischemic stroke. In fact, the use of anticoagulants is strongly cautioned in all patients with SCD, as these patients are at greater risk for intracranial hemorrhage. Heparin is only indicated as thromboprophylactic therapy in patients with SCD ≥ 18 years of age that are hospitalized with an acute medical illness.

E) INCORRECT:

Aspirin therapy, which has an antiplatelet effect, is a common adjunctive therapy in the management of an acute ischemic stroke, including in patients with SCD. Administration within 24–48 hours of symptom onset reduces the risk of recurrent stroke and improves mortality. However, another option is more appropriate for the acute management of this patient.
questions.hint: Sickled red blood cells are rigid and tend to clump along the walls of arteries, which can lead to thrombosis, infarction, and end-organ ischemia (cerebral infarction in this case).

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy is brought to the office by his father because he has been waking up frequently during the night to urinate for the past 3 months. Apart from occasional headaches, he has no other complaints. His family recently emigrated from Tanzania and his medical history is unknown. His father was diagnosed with sickle cell disease at the age of 5. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin, hematocrit, and reticulocyte count are within normal limits. A hemoglobin electrophoresis shows:


HbA

55% (N = 95–98)


HbS

43% (N = 0)


HbF

1% (N < 2)


This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with SCD are at increased risk for avascular osteonecrosis due to vasoocclusion from sickle cell build-up. Avascular osteonecrosis is characterized by infarction of the bone and marrow and most commonly affects the head of the femur and humerus. However, in patients with sickle cell trait avascular osteonecrosis is very rare, making a different complication more likely.

B) CORRECT:

Sickle cell trait is associated with renal papillary necrosis secondary to transient sickling of RBCs in the renal capillaries, which results in microthrombotic infarctions and sloughing of necrotic papillae. Renal papillary necrosis can lead to hyposthenuria (indicated by this patient's nocturia) and painless gross hematuria. Hematuria is the most common clinical finding in individuals with sickle cell trait. Other complications associated with sickle cell trait include urinary tract infections, chronic kidney disease, and renal medullary carcinoma, which can also present with painless gross hematuria.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with SCD typically develop functional asplenia by the age of 4 years because of repeated infarction secondary to vasoocclusion from sickle cell build-up (autosplenectomy). In these patients, Howell-Jolly bodies are a characteristic finding on peripheral blood smear. However, in patients with sickle cell trait, splenic infarctions are rare and mainly associated with high altitude exposure, making a different complication more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with SCD are at increased risk of cholelithiasis with pigmented gallstones because chronic hemolysis often leads to hypersaturation and precipitation of bilirubin. Compared to individuals with SCD, however, individuals with sickle cell trait have less severe hemolysis, which typically does not lead to the formation of pigmented gall stones and/or anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with SCD are at increased risk for ischemic strokes secondary to vasoocclusion from sickle cell build-up. Individuals with sickle cell trait, however, are at higher risk of a different complication.
questions.hint: The patient's hemoglobin electrophoresis reveals the presence of hemoglobin S (HbS) and a decreased proportion of hemoglobin A (HbA). These findings, in conjunction with his mild symptoms (nocturia, occasional headaches), suggest sickle cell trait.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the office for intermittent fevers and painful swelling of the left ankle for 2 weeks. She has no history of trauma to the ankle. She has a history of sickle cell disease. Current medications include hydroxyurea and acetaminophen for pain. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101.2°F) and pulse is 112/min. Examination shows a tender, swollen, and erythematous left ankle with point tenderness over the medial malleolus. A bone biopsy culture confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

P. aeruginosa osteomyelitis is seen most often in adult IV drug users. It is typically only identified in pediatric populations following puncture wounds to the foot, such as stepping on a nail. This patient has no history of acute trauma to her foot, making P. aeruginosa an unlikely cause.

B) CORRECT:

Salmonella, an encapsulated bacteria, is the most likely cause of this patient's osteomyelitis. In the US and Europe, it is the most common pathogen in SCD-associated osteomyelitis due to the functional asplenia common to this population, induced by chronic splenic occlusions and infarctions. S. aureus is the most common cause of osteomyelitis in SCD patients in Africa and the Middle East and remains the most common cause of osteomyelitis overall.

C) INCORRECT:

E. coli and other gram-negative bacteria can cause osteomyelitis in neonates, children, and adults. It is frequently identified in SCD patients with osteomyelitis. However, another organism is more commonly found.

D) INCORRECT:

Group A Streptococcus is a common cause of osteomyelitis in infants and children (up to 8% of cases). However, this patient's history of SCD makes another organism more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

As an encapsulated bacteria, S. pneumoniae is the most common cause of bacteremia, sepsis, and meningitis in patients with SCD. However, it is a less common cause of osteomyelitis.
questions.hint: A history of fevers and bone point tenderness in a child with sickle cell disease (SCD) indicates osteomyelitis. SCD predisposes to infection with encapsulated bacteria because of the functional asplenia present in most patients by the age of four.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy with sickle cell disease is brought to the office because of a 4-week history of left groin and buttock pain. The pain is worse with activity but also present at rest. He is at the 20th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), blood pressure is 115/82 mm Hg, and pulse is 84/min. Examination shows tenderness over the lateral aspect of the left hip with no swelling, warmth, or erythema. There is pain with passive abduction and internal rotation of the left hip. Leukocyte count is 8,600/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is a common hip disorder in adolescent males and can also present with pain and limited range of motion. However, this patient's low weight and absence of family history make SCFE unlikely. His underlying sickle cell disease, on the other hand, makes a different diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with sickle cell disease are at increased risk of septic arthritis due to functional asplenia (which results from recurrent infarction of the spleen). Septic arthritis can also manifest with severe hip pain and limited range of motion, which are seen in this patient. However, additional symptoms such as fever, joint swelling, and erythema would also be expected. His normal leukocyte count makes this diagnosis unlikely as well.

C) CORRECT:

Avascular osteonecrosis of the femoral head is a common complication in patients with sickle cell disease and typically manifests between 7–15 years of age. This adolescent boy's subacute hip pain and lack of systemic symptoms are characteristic of avascular osteonecrosis, which is due to trabecular bone infarction from RBC sickling and vaso-occlusion. The femoral head is commonly affected as a result of poor collateral blood supply. Other risk factors for avascular osteonecrosis of the femoral head include glucocorticoid use, alcohol use, autoimmune diseases (e.g., SLE, antiphospholipid syndrome), and Gaucher disease.

Key learning point: Avascular necrosis of the femoral head is a common complication of sickle cell disease due to bone infarction from vaso-occlusion.

D) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis is a common cause of self-limited hip pain and limping in children and is often preceded by upper respiratory tract infection. However, most patients with transient synovitis are slightly younger (< 10 years), and this patient's underlying sickle cell disease makes a different diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with sickle cell disease are at increased risk of impaired skeletal growth. The etiology is multifactorial and is at least partially due to premature closure of the long bone epiphyses. Although there is evidence of impaired growth in this patient based on his low percentile in height and weight, it would be unlikely to cause subacute, unilateral hip pain.
questions.hint: This patient's pain and examination findings suggest pathology involving the hip.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with sickle cell disease is brought to the emergency department because of high-grade fever and lethargy for 4 days. He has had a severe headache for 3 days and 2 episodes of non-bilious vomiting. His mother has refused vaccinations in the past because of their possible side effects. His temperature is 40.1°C (104.2°F). Kernig and Brudzinski signs are present. A lumbar puncture is performed. Gram stain of the cerebrospinal fluid shows gram-negative coccobacilli. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Transient or permanent sensorineural hearing loss, which is an important complication of bacterial meningitis, may occur as early as 48 hours after the onset of symptoms as a result of the spread of infection from the meninges to the cochlea via the cochlear aqueduct. In patients with sickle cell disease (SCD), multiple episodes of splenic infarction cause atrophy and fibrosis of the spleen, and by the age of 3 years most patients would have functional asplenia which increases the risk of infection with encapsulated bacteria such as H. influenzae and S. pneumoniae. The risk is further increased by the fact that the child has not received the Hib vaccine. Other common long-term neurological complications of bacterial meningitis include cognitive impairment, focal motor deficit (spasticity/paresis), and seizure disorders. Dexamethasone is recommended for children above 6 months of age with Hib meningitis because it has been shown to decrease the risk of hearing loss.

SCD is also an independent risk factor for mild sensorineural hearing loss because it can cause vaso-occlusive crisis in the narrow labyrinthine artery and/or its branches.

B) INCORRECT:

Adrenal insufficiency due to Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome is a dangerous complication of meningococcal meningitis and is due to a coagulopathy triggered by endotoxins, which may lead to hemorrhagic necrosis of the adrenal glands. Although this patient's age and functional asplenia are risk factors for patients affected with meningococcal meningitis, Gram staining of CSF would have shown gram-negative diplococci.
Image Description:

Purple nonblanching macules of various sizes, consistent with purpura (larger macules) and petechiae (smaller macules), are visible.

These findings are consistent with purpura in Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Secondary brain abscess is a very rare complication of meningitis that is seen mainly in newborns. It is typically associated with infection by Listeria monocytogenes (a gram-positive bacillus) or certain enteric gram-negative bacteria (e.g., Cronobacter, Citrobacter).
Image Description:

Cranial MRI (with contrast, axial view)

An oval lesion can be seen in the left temporal lobe, with ring-like contrast enhancement (green ring) and central necrosis (green overlay). The perifocal edema (white overlay) that is visible corresponds to the lesion. Differential diagnoses include an abscess, glioblastoma, and metastasis.

Diagnosis: abscess following advanced otitis media

D) INCORRECT:

Cerebral palsy (CP) is a possible complication of pediatric meningitis but usually occurs in meningitis affecting children younger than 3 years of age because CP is a result of insult to the developing brain. CP is unlikely to develop in a 7-year-old child.

E) INCORRECT:

Postinfectious communicating hydrocephalus resulting from impaired reabsorption of CSF in the basal cisterns (due to obstruction of subarachnoid villi) is most often seen in patients with tuberculous (TB) meningitis. Although patients with TB meningitis may present with clinical features similar to those seen in patients with meningitis due to H. influenzae, TB meningitis typically has a subacute or chronic course, not an acute course. In addition, a Gram stain would not show gram-negative coccobacilli. While postinfectious hydrocephalus (communicating or noncommunicating) can also occur as a long-term sequela of other types of bacterial meningitis, including H. influenzae, it is a rare complication.
questions.hint: Fever, headache, vomiting, and positive Kernig and Brudzinski signs indicate meningitis. The appearance of gram-negative coccobacilli in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in an unvaccinated child indicates Haemophilus influenzae.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with sharp, diffuse abdominal pain that began six hours ago and has progressively worsened. He reports feeling feverish and has had several similar episodes of abdominal and back pain in the past. His surgical history is unremarkable. He appears distressed (see lab results and reports).


Heart rate
110/min


Respiratory rate
24/min


Temperature
38.1°C




Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
85 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


MCV
88 fL
80 - 95 fL


Total bilirubin
20 μmol/L
3.5 - 16.5 μmol/L




Peripheral blood smear: Target cells and red blood cell inclusions
Abdominal ultrasound: No obvious anomalies

Which diagnosis best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute intermittent porphyria can cause diffuse abdominal pain with unremarkable imaging. However, the low hemoglobin, elevated bilirubin, and peripheral smear findings indicate hemolysis, typical of hemoglobinopathies. Recurrent pain episodes align more with vaso-occlusive phenomena, while porphyria is associated with neuropsychiatric symptoms and lacks chronic hemolysis.

B) CORRECT:

Vaso-occlusive crisis manifests with acute, diffuse pain in multiple regions, including the abdomen and back, due to microvascular occlusion in sickle cell disease. Normocytic anemia with low hemoglobin and mild hyperbilirubinemia indicates hemolysis, a key feature of sickle cell disease. Target cells and red blood cell inclusions on the peripheral smear reflect abnormal red cell morphology from repeated sickling and infarction, as well as functional asplenia. These findings highlight the pathophysiology of sickle cell disease, where deoxygenated hemoglobin polymerizes, leading to sickling, microinfarctions, and painful vaso-occlusive episodes.

Key learning point: Sickle cell disease can present with acute abdominal pain and normocytic anemia with target cells and red cell inclusion bodies on peripheral smear, indicative of a vaso-occlusive crisis.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute appendicitis typically presents with fever, tachycardia, and localized right lower quadrant abdominal pain, often with rebound tenderness. The recurrent nature of the patient's pain, normocytic anemia, mild hyperbilirubinemia, and peripheral smear findings suggest a hemoglobinopathy rather than appendicitis. The normal abdominal ultrasound further argues against appendicitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS) usually follows a diarrheal illness and presents with thrombocytopenia and renal impairment. The presence of target cells and red blood cell inclusions suggests a chronic hemolytic process, not the microangiopathic hemolysis with schistocytes seen in HUS. The recurrent pain episodes also support a different pathology.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy with sickle cell disease presents to the clinic with severe fatigue and left-sided abdominal pain that began abruptly this morning. His mother reports he appears paler than usual and has been increasingly drowsy. On examination, he is notably irritable. The spleen is palpable below the left costal margin and is visibly enlarged. There is no fever, and his oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Laboratory results show hemoglobin 30 g/L below his known baseline (reference range: 120–160 g/L). Platelets are within normal limits. He has no chest pain or respiratory symptoms.


Heart rate
130/min


Blood pressure
85/55 mm Hg


Oxygen saturation
99% on room air


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute chest syndrome presents with respiratory symptoms like chest pain, cough, and hypoxia, often with pulmonary infiltrates. The patient has normal oxygen saturation and no respiratory complaints, which are inconsistent with acute chest syndrome. The absence of pulmonary findings suggests a non-pulmonary complication.

B) INCORRECT:

Vaso-occlusive crisis in sickle cell disease manifests as acute pain from microvascular occlusions, often in bones or chest. The severe hemoglobin drop and splenomegaly indicate blood sequestration, not localized ischemia. Left-sided abdominal pain and splenomegaly are uncommon in vaso-occlusive events.

C) INCORRECT:

Aplastic crisis involves transient erythropoiesis failure, often due to parvovirus B19, causing a sharp hemoglobin drop. It does not typically present with splenic enlargement or left-sided abdominal pain. The enlarged spleen and hypovolemic signs suggest blood sequestration rather than erythropoiesis cessation.

D) CORRECT:

Splenic sequestration crisis in sickle cell disease occurs when sickled red blood cells accumulate in the spleen, causing sudden blood pooling. This leads to an acute drop in circulating hemoglobin and hypovolemia, manifesting as severe fatigue, pallor, tachycardia, and hypotension. A rapidly enlarging, tender spleen is a key diagnostic feature. The significant decrease in hemoglobin from the patient's baseline highlights the severity of blood sequestration within the spleen.

Key learning point: In sickle cell disease, sequestration crisis is characterized by acute anemia, splenomegaly, and hypovolemic shock due to sudden pooling of blood in the spleen.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department with intense pain in his left femur for the past day. He refuses to bear weight and appears irritable. He has a history of multiple admissions for episodes of severe bone pain. He appears dehydrated. Physical examination reveals diffuse tenderness over the area, without obvious external injury.

Temperature
39.0°C

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute osteomyelitis can present with fever, localized bone pain, and tenderness. However, the recurrent nature of the bone pain and absence of focal signs like erythema or swelling suggest a pattern inconsistent with an isolated infection. The dehydration and recurrent episodes align more with a vaso-occlusive crisis.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute rheumatic fever typically follows streptococcal pharyngitis and presents with migratory polyarthritis, not isolated bone pain. The absence of preceding sore throat and other major Jones criteria, along with the recurrent bone pain, makes this diagnosis unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

Sickle cell vaso-occlusive crisis manifests when deoxygenation causes hemoglobin S to polymerize, leading red blood cells to sickle and obstruct small vessels. This obstruction reduces perfusion, causing ischemia and acute pain, often in long bones. Dehydration increases blood viscosity, promoting sickling and exacerbating crises. The recurrent severe bone pain and history of multiple admissions align with sickle cell disease's vaso-occlusive episodes. The interplay between hemoglobin mutation and environmental triggers, such as dehydration, precipitates these crises.

Key learning point: Sudden and severe bone pain in a child, along with fever and dehydration, is indicative of a vaso-occlusive crisis, which is characteristic of sickle cell disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis is characterized by chronic joint inflammation, morning stiffness, and joint swelling. The acute, severe bone pain and recurrent episodes do not align with the chronic inflammation seen in this condition. The absence of joint-specific symptoms further supports this.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl with sickle cell anemia is admitted to the hospital for the third time this year with chest pain, fever, and shortness of breath. Previous admissions were treated with intravenous fluids, analgesics, and antibiotics for similar findings, which resolved fully each time. Her immunizations are current, and prophylactic penicillin was discontinued at age five. She complains of moderate fatigue and mild dyspnea on exertion between these episodes (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
78 g/L
112 - 165 g/L


Reticulocyte
3.5%
0.2 - 1.2%



Chest X-ray: New left lower lobe infiltration
Which medication is most likely to reduce the frequency of her acute chest syndrome and pain crises?

choices.text: Chronic monthly red blood cell transfusions

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic monthly transfusions can lower sickle hemoglobin levels and are used in high-risk situations, such as preventing stroke in children with abnormal transcranial doppler velocities. However, they are not typically used as a primary prophylactic strategy for reducing pain crises and acute chest syndrome due to risks like iron overload and alloimmunization.

B) CORRECT:

Hydroxyurea is the preferred medication for reducing the frequency of acute chest syndrome and pain crises in sickle cell anemia. It increases fetal hemoglobin (HbF) production, which interferes with hemoglobin S polymerization, reducing red blood cell sickling and vaso-occlusive events. This leads to fewer episodes of acute chest syndrome and pain crises. Hydroxyurea also improves hematologic parameters and decreases hospital admissions, making it an effective strategy for modifying the clinical course of sickle cell disease.

Key learning point: Hydroxyurea is the most effective drug to reduce the incidence of acute chest syndrome and vaso-occlusive crises in sickle cell anemia by increasing fetal hemoglobin levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic penicillin prevents infections from encapsulated organisms in young children with sickle cell disease. It is discontinued after age five when children are fully immunized. It does not address vaso-occlusion, the primary cause of acute chest syndrome and pain crises in older patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Folic acid supports DNA synthesis and cell division, aiding erythropoiesis in sickle cell anemia. However, it does not affect red blood cell sickling or vaso-occlusion, which are central to pain crises and acute chest syndrome. Its role is supportive, not preventive, for vaso-occlusive episodes.

questions.text: An 8-year-old with hemoglobin SS disease has frequent pain crises and no palpable spleen on exam. Which mechanism best explains his decreased splenic function?

choices.text: Congenital absence of normal splenic tissue
Repeated intravascular sickling with progressive splenic infarction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Congenital asplenia can occur in isolation or with heterotaxy syndromes, but it does not fit the clinical picture of an 8-year-old with hemoglobin SS disease. In sickle cell disease, the spleen is initially present but undergoes progressive infarction due to repeated vaso-occlusive events, leading to autosplenectomy.

B) CORRECT:

Sickle cell disease involves abnormal hemoglobin S, which polymerizes under low oxygen tension, causing red blood cells to sickle. These sickled cells obstruct the splenic microvasculature, leading to repeated ischemia and infarction. Over time, chronic vaso-occlusive events cause scarring and fibrosis, resulting in autosplenectomy, where the spleen becomes non-functional and shrunken. This loss of splenic function increases susceptibility to infections by encapsulated organisms, highlighting the need for immunization and prophylaxis in these patients.

Key learning point: Sickle cell disease can lead to hyposplenism due to repeated splenic infarctions and eventual autosplenectomy.

C) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune destruction involves immune-mediated injury with autoantibodies targeting splenic tissue, seen in systemic autoimmune disorders. In hemoglobin SS disease, splenic dysfunction results from repeated vaso-occlusion by sickled erythrocytes, causing infarctions and fibrosis, not an immune-mediated mechanism.

D) INCORRECT:

Extramedullary hematopoiesis occurs in conditions with marrow failure or increased hematopoietic demand, such as thalassemia intermedia. In hemoglobin SS disease, repeated vaso-occlusive events cause splenic ischemia and infarction, leading to fibrosis and shrinkage, not extramedullary hematopoiesis.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man with sickle cell disease presents to the clinic with sudden severe pain in his left femur for the past six hours. He reports no preceding trauma. He appears distressed. Examination reveals localized tenderness over the mid-thigh without swelling or erythema. He describes his pain as throbbing and unrelenting (see lab results and report).

Temperature
38.2°C



Test
Result

130 - 170 g/L
